net.netii.platinumcoding.ini

Class INIFileWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.netii.platinumcoding.ini.INIFileWriter

  • public class INIFileWriter
extends java.lang.Object
    This class is used for creating new categories and elements within a specific INI file. If you want to modify existing elements, see INIElementWriter.

    When you want to create an element or a category within an INI file, you use this class to do so. An example has been provided for every method of this class.

    The following text is content of the file "Example.ini", which is used in all of the examples: 

     ; Window properties
 [Window]
 Width=640
 Height=480
 
 ; Render properties
 [Properties]
 vSync=true
 DoubleBuffer=true
    If you wanted to add another category to the file, or add an element to a category, you would use the addCategory(String) method to create a new category, and addElement(String, String, Object) to create an element. 

     // ...
 
 // Initializes a writer
 INIFileWriter writer = new INIFileWriter(new java.io.File("Example.ini"));
 
 // Used for adding a new element to the file
 INIElement element;	
 
 // Successfully adds the new category "Color"
 writer.addCategory("Color");
 
 // Does not add the category "Window" because it already exists
 writer.addCategory("Window");
 
 // Creates a new element under Color (Text=Black)
 String category = "Color";
 String key = "Text";
 Object value = "Black";
 writer.addElement(category, key, value);
 
 // Creates a new element that will be under Color, as Background=White
 String key2 = "Background";
 Object value2 = "White";
 element = new INIElement(writer.getINIFile(), category, key2, value2);
 
 // ...
    And the content of the Example.ini file is now: 

     ; Window properties
 [Window]
 Width=640
 Height=480
 
 ; Render properties
 [Properties]
 vSync=true
 DoubleBuffer=true
 
 [Color]
 Text=Black
    But why is the Background=White in the file? Because the INIFileWriter never actually wrote it to the file. Just because you created an INIElement and set the file that it belongs to, does not mean that it will be in the file. For it to be successfully added to the file, it must be added via INIFileWriter.

    So, to fix the problem, just add the following line after the element is initialized: 

     writer.addElement(element);

      INIFileWriter(java.io.File file)
      Creates an INIFileWriter that will write elements and categories to the specified file.

      • INIFileWriter

        public INIFileWriter(java.io.File file)
        Creates an INIFileWriter that will write elements and categories to the specified file.
        Parameters:

    • Method Detail

      • addCategory

        public void addCategory(java.lang.String category)
        Adds a category to the current INI file. If the category already exists, then the category will not be created.
        Parameters:
        category - The category to be added to the file

      • addElement

        public void addElement(java.lang.String category,
              java.lang.String key,
              java.lang.Object value)
        Adds an element to the desired category. If the element already exists, the element is NOT overwritten. Instead, nothing is done. If you want to override a value, see INIElementWriter.setValue(Object).
        Parameters:
        category - The desired category to add the element to
        key - The key that will represent the element
        value - The value of the element

      • addElement

        public void addElement(INIElement element)
        Adds an element to the desired category. If the element already exists, it will not override the value. If you wish to change the value of an element, see INIElementWriter.setValue(Object) Note: The element's INI file will be overwritten to the INIFileWriter's INI file
        Parameters:
        element - An element containing a category, key, and a value.

      • getINIFile

        public java.io.File getINIFile()
        Gets the current INI file that is being written to.
        Returns:
        The INI file being written to
